description: A "3D" board game distributed in a bag with jelly beans for fuel.  Promotional item for the Disney/Pixar film, "Cars", with two circular tracks linked with a flyover section of track to permit moving from the outer to the inner track.  Movement is determined by an ineffectual 6 sided spinner rather than a dice.  Cards are randomly placed on the spaces and turned over when the player lands on them.  Players must collect 6 "organic fuel" cards to progress to the inner track.  "Every time you get an organic fuel card you also get a high octane jelly."

Trio actually comes with two sets of rules.
It uses a custom set of player cards labeled with RUN, SET, RUN/SET, AP, TRIO and valued from 1 through 9.
The object is to score 30 points by discarding runs, sets, pairs and other combinations to the discard pile.

The second game plays 2-6 players, who try to be the first to collect the right cards to match any three of the four control cards dealt to each player at the beginning of the game.

This is a Chilean trivia game from 1987. Comes with 6 books of question with the following categories:

     Sports/Recreation
     Natural Science
     Social Science
     TV/Movies/Show Business
     Art
     Trivia


You roll the dice and move in a circular board. The square you are in determines the category. To choose the question you have to roll 3 dice in order, so if for example you rolled a 5 then a 2 and finally a 3, then you have to answer question number 523.
Each number of question comes with 2 questions actually, one more difficult than the other, so the game can be played by parents and children.
The first player to answer correctly one answer of each category when standing in a star square wins the game.

From the publisher:

Preschoolers love the happy animal scenes, deep colors and soft feel of We R FUN’s new preschool edition of “Life on the Farm”. Designed for the Ages 3 - 7 demographic, the soft non-toxic foam playmat (for floor play) is a huge 5-piece puzzle. When assembled, the playmate becomes the gameboard. Match colors to move - land on an animal square and get a matching animal puzzle piece to put into a soft barn puzzle. Fill the barn with animals to win. This game quickly became a favorite when tested by early education specialists.

The Worst-Case Scenario card Game - Cooking

Back of the Box:
Boost your kitchen savvy. Learn to survive culinary catastrophes - from opening a bottle of wine without a corkscrew to fixing an over-salted soup. Whether it's dinner for 10 or a meal on the go - you'll be prepared to handle any cooking crisis.

Contents
55 Cards with 108 Questions

Object of the Game
Be the first to consecutively survive 5 scenarios

Players take turns to ask each other the questions on the cards: a correct answer means that they continue asking, wrong means that they pass the questions to the player who was answering who then proceeds.

For children Ages 4 - 8.

A great game for little folks! Loads of fun trying to make the biggest, daffiest, silliest sandwich of all! [from box]

Roll the dice and move around the board. When you land on a picture of the refrigerator, choose a food item to add to your sandwich. If a player lands on a puppy or kitty square, an ingredient is lost.

From the Educational Insights catalog:

Panda-Go-Round is a fast paced race game of "turn and find," where each turn of the tube reveals a new expression on the panda's face, from happy or sad to sleepy - even surprised! Be the first to exactly match the expression on the panda's face with the one on the card and claim the card. Corresponding symbols on the tubes and inside the cards make the game self-checking. The player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner. Builds visual discrimination skills, a key to reading success. Includes 2 face-maker tubes and 16 cards.

Ages 4 and up.

Heroes of the Blitzkrieg relives the desperate struggle for France in May 1940.  Play as the Germans, French, and Belgians. Employ cavalry, Char B1 tanks, Germans Panzers, and much more as you re-fight the German invasion of France.

6 geomorphic maps plus a sheet of overlays.
Over 420 counters, representing the men and equipment
16 scenarios
16 New Skill Cards, providing Leaders and Heroes with special abilities.
Complete V3 LnL Rules, plus the Heroes of the Blitzkrieg specific rules.    
Player's aid charts. dice, and box.

This game is no longer available and can be found in Lock 'n Load Tactical: Heroes in Defiance

February of 1994. The Argentine military retakes power through a coup de etat. The Argentine civil government manages to find exile in neighboring Uruguay. The Argentine military issues an ultimatum to Uruguay to hand over the fugitives or face an invasion. Brazil guarantees the defense of Uruguay in the event of a Argentine invasion. Argentina launches a surprise invasion of Uruguay precipitating a counter attack from the Brazilians thus starting the war of the Pampas.

The war of the Pampas is a Brazilian designed Alternate history wargame of a war between Argentina vs. Uruguay and Brazil in an alternate early 90s.

The game consists of 169 counters representing the military forces of Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. 12 pages of rules. and special rules such as artillery, air support and more...

From Playroom Catalog:

Be the first to reach the Temple of the Monkey in this Action packed card game of jungle adventure!  Each player takes on the role of a daring explorer racing along a unique path to the temple, battling raging rapids, dangerous predators, and most importantly, each other!  Every step along the path comes with its own challenges, and explorers must be prepared for whatever comes their way.

Players must travel down their own set of path cards, representing the obstacles standing between them and the Temple.  Use your equipment cards to overcome the hurdles in your path, and your tactics to foul up your opponents efforts, but most of all, use your wits as you race to the Temple of the Monkey!

Players roll the dice and completes a driving test in order to move their token through the driving circuit.

Contains a road safety message from Jack Brabham.

Produced by "Ampol - The Australian Company".

This cardgame is a multi-player solitaire. The deck consists of 96 cards (hence the name), 6 of each in the numbers 1 through 16. You can be as many players as you like, but each players will need his own deck.

One player shuffles his deck and draws the cards, one by one, telling the others what he drew, so all players will get their cards out in the same order (similar mechanic to Take it Easy).

The point is to build stacks of cards going from 1 to 16. When the last card is drawn points are awarded for how many complete stacks you've managed to build.

The players are drawing subject cards and rolling letter dice. Ie. the subjects could be Capitols, animals, female artists, mountains and cold drinks, and the letters could be A, E, G, H and P. 
Then the players will write down answers that matches these subjects and letters, receiving points for the answers given. More points are scored for answers you are the only one having.

Bendominoes play like regular dominoes, but each piece is curved, which offers different challenges and ways to control the game.

Ages 5 and up.

The object of the game is to be the player to have the most points when the game ends. (Copied from the game's instructions)
Players roll a die and move their token first to complete the 'car' track, then to use their boats to move to different islands.  Different spaces will allow players to draw a card from the elephant deck.  Alternatively players may visit shops to collect souvenir cards.  When a player reaches the end of the track the game ends.

Oware is one of the most played games in the Mancala Family of pit and pebbles games. It is the National game of Ghana and the word "oware" means "He She Marries". The mythology behind the name is believed by many to be the result of a wedding between a man and a woman and the dowry (represented by fields (pits) and seeds. Basically, you're playing for fruitful paddocks.

The game as played in Ghana is a social event and is commonly played on the street. Heckling, banging the fist and mocking are all allowed. The game is also used in education among the Asanti children for the development of maths skills.

Most of the oware available in Ghana is hand carved and comes with traditional symbols of the Asanti people carved into the wood. The traditional playing seeds are Bonduc seeds, a bright green seed with a hard shell. Stones and sometimes recycled glass are used.

As for the other games in the Mancala Family, the rules differ from country to country; however, for Oware there is an international organization which sets the standard.

The basic object of the game is to capture more seeds than your opponent. This is done by landing the last seed you are "sowing" in a pit on the opponent's side which already contains one or two seeds. Other rules allow multiple captures and the avoidance of "stalemates".

Online Play

     Yucata (turn-based)

Binary is a series of 4 games that use a unique deck of cards.  One side of the deck is all black the other side is all white.
The games require a basic knowledge of binary numbers, which the rules provide.

Binary I - a basic game of each player dealing out 4 cards and the highest number takes the pot. (an introduction into binary numbers)

Binary II - similar to Binary I, but players lay the 4 cards one at a time.

Binary III - similar to Binary II, but players lay the 4 cards one at a time, allowing players to raise if they believe they will have the highest number

Binary IV - players across from the table play with the same 4 cards to change it into the highest number.  Each plays from their own perspective.

From the press release:

The Gut-Busting Game that’s a Blast! Gassy Gus is the hilarious game that’s a blast for all ages! Players use cards to “feed” Gus all sorts of gaseous foods – from broccoli to baked beans. With each tasty dish players must pump up Gus and watch his belly grow bigger and bigger. Watch out for the big blast of “gas”! You never know when Gus will have a blow-out and give you a stinky penalty. Be the first to feed Gus all your food and win!

Dear Judge Ichiro: the Board Game’ is a group game for 3 or more players derived from the novel Dear Judge Ichiro by Trevor Ryan (Zeus Publications).  
It is based on problem solving, specifically anagrams, listening comprehension, parables, and proverbs.

Home Page: http://www.geocities.com/kevinbonbevan/index.htm
Minis-rules for 1600-1870. Skirmish level, up to about 40 men per player. Free download.

Australian Trivia Game

Over 2000 Questions in the following catagories:

People
Places
Slang
Sport
Animals & Plants
History

And the wacky activity "Up The Creek" category.

Packaged in an Australian esky!

In Bummer, players use 5 dice to try to score points.  They set aside scoring dice and may continue with the rest.

Bummer predates Farkle and has different scoring methods.  Players score on 1s and 5s and also three of a kind, four of a kind and straights in a single roll.

This game features 10 scaled bowling pins, 3 bowling balls, and a real return track, an adjustable spring bowler, scoring pads.

The game also includes an application for a junior bowling league.

From the box cover; "A game of fun and skill for the whole family."

Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football was a playable yet highly detailed simulation of pro football in the days before the NFL and AFL consolidated. (Tarkenton was a New York Giant quarterback at the time – before he led the Vikings to three Super Bowls.)

The game was advanced for the time, and very much a simulation. The game used 23 offensive basic plays and 8 defensive lines. Unlike some contemporaries and many lesser football games, the proper defense will limit the damage of a great roll. Despite the limited number of offensive plays, there are plenty of choices since the plays can showcase feature positions. Also, beyond the 8 defensive setups, the defensive player can also have the choice of which player to 'key' on. Of course, double-covering the wrong receiver will allow a lesser roll to have a higher result.

The true advancement for the game system was the yearly 'rating' of each team on their defensive and offensive line in each of these plays. Thus, when you played two teams, there was a die roll modifier for each play based on each defense.

The clock functions were also very good, allowing a true 'two minute drill' and the use of real game strategies.

Fran Tarkenton's Pro Football is a great time capsule with a look at the teams in the 1960s, before they merged to become the NFC and AFC.

4th Street Baseball is a baseball simulation game using individual ratings to recreate big league baseball action.  Ratings are printed in booklet format on perforated cardstock.  They measure 3.5" x 2.5" (the same size as a bubble-gum card).
   The game starts with the pitcher.  Each pitcher is rated for his ability to get the ball over the plate, the likelihood of him giving up the long ball, walk to strikeout ratio, hits allowed, etc.
   Each hitter has been rated for average, extra-base potential, strikeouts and walks, base running, stealing, bunting, and lefty-righty hitting. In addition, pitchers and hitters are rated for defensive range, error frequency, outfielder-catcher arms, and infielders ability to turn the double play.
   Five dice are employed in 4th Street Baseball...one twenty-sided (d20), two ten-sided (d10), and two six-sided (d6). 
   Play starts by determining the count.  The two d10 are rolled and the count is determined by looking at the pitcher's count column.  If the pitcher gets ahead in the count, his ratings, along with all of the defensive players behind him, increase.  If he falls behind, then the increase is instead given to the hitter.  The defense is allowed to position its players and selects a strategy card (fastball, breaking ball, pitchout, etc.).  The offense, likewise, selects a strategy card (hit and run, steal, etc.).  All five dice are rolled, the strategy cards are revealed, and the play continues by finding a "matchup" on the pitcher's card.  Matchups vary from balls hit to a specific fielder, to batter-pitcher battles, to ballpark and defensive positioning effects.  Once a matchup has been determined, the defender's rating is subtracted from the hitter's rating and the result is compared to the d20.  If the result is less than or equal to the d20, the hitter wins the matchup and the final result of the play is read off the hitter by adding the two d6 and referring to the appropriate column.  If the d20 result is higher, then the play result is found similarly on the defensive player.

The game comes with a book (or two books, depending upon the season) full of baseball player ratings which are perforated to 2.5" x 3.5" (the same size as a bubble-gum card), baseball fields (printed on 8.5" x 11" card stock, for each team), dice, strategy cards, an easy-to-read results chart, and score sheets.  All players are rated for the 2005 season, except those with less than 25 at bats or innings pitched, or pitchers who had 2 or less starts.

Just as honeybees move from flower to flower collecting nectar to create honey, you'll move around the Spelling Beez game board collecting letters to create words. With two levels of play, children of all ages will enjoy this unique and educational spelling game. While younger children work to collect letters that spell simple words, older children are challenged by collecting letters for more difficult words. Older children will also share and learn interesting facts about honeybees as they try to collect the most pollen and nectar points to win the game. Spelling Beez is all you need to learn your ABC's.

Ages 4 -8

Contents:  Spelling Beez Game Board; 80 Pollen/Nectar Cards; 60 Spelling Beez Cards; Honeycomb Score Sheets; 4 Worker Bee Playing Pieces; Rules Booklet

MathAnimals is an exciting game that teaches and reinforces addition, subtraction and multiplication skills for children of all ages. With the roll of a die, players race around the colorful game board trying to land their playing piece on the animal that represents the highest number. Then they either add, subtract or multiply the number on the die to the number they have landed on. The first to reach the "winning goal", a pre-set number that can change with each new game, is the winner!  With more than 6 variations of game play, MathAnimals will continue to stimulate learning and grow with your child for years to come. Ages 5 and up
Rev the bug up and set it in the center of the board.  Watch as it spins out into one of the colored holes. That player gets to move his scoring peg.

From the back of the box:

"To play the game, suspects (called players) make their getaway beginning and ending at Rockington Estate. Unlucky players will wear the disguise or go to Da Pokey. The lucky player landing on the Outrageous Journalist (sticking his microphone out of a manhole) will collect $10 grand.

"The player collecting the most evidence wins, and in this game evidence can be bought and sold."

This simple and colorful boardgame was meant to satirize the many court trails which fueled a media frenzy in the early nineties.

Dai (or great) shogi is one of several large Shogi games that date from the Middle Ages of Japan.  It is thought to be a precursor of today's standard shogi game.  It is played on a 15×15 board.  Each player starts the game with sixty-five pieces of twenty-nine different types.  Unlike shogi, dai shogi does not permit "drops".

To win the game all players most get one naturepicture (containing 6 cards) each. But this most be done before a picture of pollution are finished.

Components:
1 Rulebook (in Swedish)
1 Board
1 Dice
4 Markers
24 Cards
The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Gloucestershire, in the United Kingdom.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Hull, in the United Kingdom.

The classic boardgame takes on a new shape in this Liverpool edition. Featuring stars from the current squad alongside heroes from Liverpool's illustrious past and two of the club's greatest managers, this version of Monopoly requires players to accumulate wealth by aquiring stands and stadiums. Community Chest and Chance cards are replaced by Home and Away cards. It's an absolute must for all Liverpool fans!

Featuring stars from the current squad alongside heroes from United's glorious past and two of football's greatest ever managers, this version of Monopoly requires players to accumulate wealth by aquiring stands and stadiums. Community Chest and Chance cards are replaced by Home and Away cards. It's an absolute must for all Reds fans!

Thunderbirds to the rescue with 6 collectable die-cast vehicles! Complete with Evil Hood mover for optional play.
Join the Tracy family, Lady Penelope and all your other favourites. Race around the board on an International Rescue mission. Buy and sell vehicles, characters and locations. For extra fun you can add the special Evil Hood gameplay. Stay cool under pressure – may the richest player win!

Inflatable Monopoly contains original cards, money and metal pieces in a handy carry case. Approx. size when inflated 700mm x 700mm x 300mm.
